text: I've moved many many monkeys and other
animals from Greece mainly to Holland
but this is the the biggest thing I've
done so far on my own and it is all on
my own and that's what made it so
difficult this is the crate that we're
going to ship vivos to san diego in it's
been specially made to IATA regulations
as you can see it's got double doors
this is at one door this is the second
and it just makes it very secure inside
you've noticed he's got a built-in water
feature on the front door we've also got
an inspection panel so that we can see
inside
we had a slight problem we couldn't get
him in the crates we tried to get him in
without anesthetic but it wasn't
possible so we've just given him a job
and leaving quiet for 5-10 minutes till
he goes down then we've got to get
you'll be lifted on top onto a little
pallet and then that will be loaded into
the back of the trailer we got up at
five o'clock this morning left at six
and six-hour journey through very nice
journey up over the mountains that's why
it takes so long
with the cargo at Athens Airport chivas
has just been unloaded and been taken
out now through to customs to be checked
in and he'll be put in a nice quiet spot
until we get to load him but it's quite
a bit of documentation still to be
finished
so I'm staying at the airport now till
he's loaded we've just topped up his
water and fingers crossed her next off
London and he Leng goes to the
quarantine station where they'll receive
him and he'll be fed and watered tonight
ready for the flight so he'll get a bit
of a chance to refresh and we fly out
tomorrow afternoon to San Diego and
they're already emailed me they're ready
and waiting for him so he's got a little
reception committee waiting in San Diego
so hopefully tomorrow night
San Diego he'll be in his new home
